brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a rule that reports vetoed @Alternative beans in CDI. A bean is considered vetoed when it is annotated with @Vetoed or it is declared in a vetoed package.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'vetoed-alternative-bean' checks all classes in the application. If a class or its package is annotated with '@Vetoed', it then checks all methods in that class. If any method is annotated with '@Alternative', it asserts false and generates a message indicating that a vetoed @Alternative bean has been detected, specifying the method and class names.
new_built-in_functions_explanation if an: The rule uses the following built-in functions: getClasses, hasAnnotation, getFamily, getMethods, getName, getFQN. No new functions were introduced.
PRE_model_validation: The rule syntax appears to be correct according to the RSL syntax. It uses only existing built-in functions and follows the structure of the provided example rules.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. 'https://docs.jboss.org/cdi/spec/2.0/cdi-spec.html#alternative_stereotypes': This page from the official CDI specification discusses the use of @Alternative and @Vetoed annotations, which is directly relevant to the rule.
2. 'https://www.baeldung.com/java-cdi': This tutorial from Baeldung provides a practical example of using CDI, including the use of @Alternative and @Vetoed, which helps in understanding the context of the rule.
